  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
With wildfires ravishing the Southeast, a blaze that’s
  torched a Los Angeles park, a tropical storm lingering off the East Coast and
  massive flooding in the Midwest, the story of the day is nature’s fury
  being unleashed on the United States. 
 
Cynthia Bowers will report from Missouri, where riverside towns are under water
  after at least 20 levees were washed over, resulting in the worst flooding in
  more than a decade. 
 
The deluge that caused the flooding is a remnant of
  the storm system that leveled the town of Greensburg,
  Kansas. President
  Bush toured the destruction in Greensburg
  today. Hari Sreenivasan will have that story as well as more on the debate over
  whether the National Guard is being stretched too thin in wartime to
  adequately respond to disasters at home.
 
On the West Coast, a wildfire is threatening Los Angeles landmarks,
  including a famed park's conservatory and zoo. Sandra Hughes will have that
  report. And Bianca Solorzano is on the other side of the country reporting on
  the massive fires that are working their way through southern Georgia and northern Florida.
 
Meanwhile, Vice President Dick Cheney is in Baghdad, on a surprise stop to urge Iraq's warring factions to find
  more common ground. Mark Strassmann is there and will have our report.
 
What's the newest popular export from China?
  Its language. American students are learning Mandarin in droves, and it's
  becoming a popular subject in schools from Maryland
  to Washington
  state. Barry Petersen will report on the language’s wide appeal in America.
 
Finally, we’re going to introduce you to a
  poet whose services reach an unusual market – the supermarket. Zach Houston hawks his
  wares, commissioned poems, outside of grocery stores in Berkeley, California.
  He may not be a Wordsworth, but what comes out of this wordsmith’s
  typewriter just might surprise you. John Blackstone will have the story.
 
I hope you’ll join us,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
